title: BlackHatCoiner
author: BlackHatCoiner
content: There's a common misconception dominating, that holding bitcoin does not produce anything, and that bitcoiners encourage everyone to put their money on a "static asset" that is unproductive to society, instead of putting them somewhere that would fund and allow the production of new goods and services. In other words, holding hard money slows down economic growth. At first glance, the logic may seem sound. But, when examined through the lens of a sound, Austrian economist, it quickly falls apart. Holding bitcoin represents a safeguard against the relentless money printing caused by central banks. Considering that central banks are arguably one of the most harmful institutions ever devised by humanity, it's not only reasonable to assert that bitcoin generates value but also an understatement to merely classify it as a "good or service"; bitcoin is the cornerstone of civilization. What exactly does it generate? It lowers humans' time preference. It allows you to transfer value into the future, which as result, makes you less present-oriented. This discount of the present for the future is what has allowed humans to develop capital goods, which have increased economic growth by orders of magnitude over the course of time.  Putting central banks out of business would enormously increase productivity, because fiat currency has encouraged everyone to live fragile lives and discount their future for the present, because the future is always uncertain under a fiat standard!Send it to a no-coiner.

comments.author: mindrust
comments.body: Bitcoin is indeed not producing any income. It is like gold. Being useful and being income productive are different concepts. Gold is useful. People use it every day in their lives. It is in their electronic devices. Lots of people use bitcoin too for various purposes.However, both bitcoin and gold are creating value. When I use bitcoin to send money to some other person to get some service or product in return, I am getting a job done. That creates value. It increases bitcoin’s intrinsic value.Just like how factories put gold in electronics. There is a demand for gold without a doubt because it doesn’t have an alternative.When people say bitcoin doesn’t produce anything, they mean it doesn’t produce any income which is true because bitcoin is not a stock. It doesn’t have a balance sheet or income statement.

comments.author: apogio
comments.body: Quote from: mindrust on December 11, 2024, 01:03:12 PMWhen people say bitcoin doesn’t produce anything, they mean it doesn’t produce any income which is true because bitcoin is not a stock. It doesn’t have a balance sheet or income statement.The Wall Street folks, consider something as an investment only if it produces a consistent cash flow. Because, essentially, the details about this specific cash flow are the determining factor about whether the investment is worth it or not.So, they claim Bitcoin is only valuable because people decide to give it value. And their counter-argument is that if people stop buying bitcoin then it doesn't have any value on its own.But they forget that if a large company shuts down, or if people don't buy its stocks, then the stock holders will only have a piece of paper.

comments.author: memehunter
comments.body: What is the value of BTC without fiat, it is zero. And who do you think will have more control over Bitcoin mining/holdings (voting power)? People who already have means (people who have lots of fiat).So the value of BTC is not inherent in the fact that it is some sort of magic bullet that can kill centralized banks and facilitate the decentralization of economic power to the common man.Bitcoin will always be more powerful as one of the currencies rather than becoming the only game in the town. Regarding the value proposition you laid for BTC, I find merit in your argument and I have to admit that I have come across these arguments (as anyone who knows BTC) a million times before but the way you contextualized it I think this is my first time.I want to add that IMO the real value of BTC is not in holding and treating it as an asset but rather watching it keep moving in the economy as blood in the human body.

Therefore, yes, apart from central bankers, I believe life would be better.QuoteOur life will be infinitely better if there was no crime and the governments wouldn't spend billions of dollars on armies.Governments need resources to enable war. To gather these resources they need to take them from somewhere. Fiat currency is empirically the most effective weapon that allows them to have infinite resources, by stealing from the people's purchasing power endlessly. When they cannot steal through inflation, the government cannot fund a war forever, and it stops. The same applies to crime. Aside from the fact that central banking is itself criminal, when people adopt a more future-oriented mindset, it significantly shapes their value system. How good citizen are you if you have no idea what the future holds? Very little, and that is evident in places with hyperinflation.

comments.author: Alpha Marine
comments.body: If they argue that "Bitcoin that has been held in a wallet for a long time produces nothing while it's being held," then they're right, but that cannot be regarded as a flaw when talking about investment.  It is being held for a purpose. There is no law, not even a financial or economic law that states that every investment must produce something while it is being held. It's just another argument that has been spun up to discredit Bitcoin.I bet these same people will call me a smart investor if I buy gold and decide to keep it for a long. It will be a great investment if I buy a gold ring or jewellery because it can be worth much more in years to come, but they use the same argument to talk down in bitcoin.It's like the same argument where they say things like "bitcoin is a scam because it was created out of nothing".What was fiat made out of? precios stones? It's also created out of nothing but nobody seems to have a problem with that.

(Or long/short it when the time is right)It is pretty much the same with bitcoin.When you buy a company stock you check its ability to make money, its debt amount, cash flow, ratios etc and then you’ll make an educated guess about its future price. Since you are buying it, you think it is cheap at the moment according to its current data and you expect them to be better in the future.When you buy a commodity (which bitcoin also is according to the US), you betting on that the demand for that commodity (bitcoin in this case) will be higher in the future and that demand will drive the prices higher. That kind of thinking assumes that the current market prices are honest and are not being manipulated by somebody.In honest markets an investor with common sense thinks like that. comments.author: d5000
comments.body: I'm more in line with mindrust here. The value of Bitcoin in my opinion is rooted in the fact that it provides an infrastructure for a payment network with a degree of decentralization, security and censorship resistance never seen before in the history of humanity.For me the deflationary aspect can be indeed an advantage due to the major investment in capital goods, but even a Bitcoin-Standard society anyway needs some options to deal with economic cycles so for me Bitcoin will never be the "one and only" currency-like asset of the world. Even in a crypto-only world there will be inflationary assets, like memecoins.The savings ratio (could be described abstractly as deflationary vs. inflationary assets & consumption) is also not really better if it tends to 100%. It should be higher in many countries than now, but there are examples like Denmark (one of the lowest in Europe) with a relatively low savings ratio and high productivity. There has be some equilibrium between capital goods & consumption goods.In one thing we agree however: the quote in the OP title is completely wrong.

An even better would be to leave the individual invest their money anywhere they want without any permission. QuoteFiat and the Central Bank are a necessary evilI don't think they are necessary, but they will absolutely exist, probably for as long as humans will exist. Quote from: d5000 on December 11, 2024, 04:40:57 PMThe savings ratio (could be described abstractly as deflationary vs. inflationary assets & consumption) is also not really better if it tends to 100%. It should be higher in many countries than now, but there are examples like Denmark (one of the lowest in Europe) with a relatively low savings ratio and high productivity. There has be some equilibrium between capital goods & consumption goods.But, I never said that you should leave all your funds in savings. What I emphasized is that the ability to save for the future is a crucial aspect of civilization. This "equilibrium" between capital goods and consumption goods emerges when people can freely save for the future, rather than being forced to either watch their value erode overtime or make risky investments.
